in one of <as0>Vasishṭha</as0>’s hymns he is represented as king <as0>Su-dās</as0>’s family priest, an office to which <as0>Viṡvā-mitra</as0> also aspired; in another hymn <as0>Vasishṭha</as0> claims to have been inspired by <as0>Varuṇa</as0>, and in another [<ls>RV. vii, 33, 11</ls>] he is called the son of the <as0>Apsaras</as0> <as0>Urvaṡī</as0> by <as0>Mitra</as0> and <as0>Varuṇa</as0>, whence his patronymic <as0>Maitrāvaruṇi</as0>; column5: “The Auspicious one”, <ab>N.</ab> of the disintegrating or destroying and reproducing deity (who constitutes the third god of the <as0ns>Hindū</as0ns> <as0>Trimūrti</as0> or Triad, the other two being <as0>Brahmā</as0> “the creator” and <as0>Vishṇu</as0> “the preserver”; in the <as0>Veda</as0> the only <ab>N.</ab> of the destroying deity was <as0>Rudra</as0> “the terrible god”, but in later times it became usual to give that god the euphemistic <ab>N.</ab> <as0>Ṡiva</as0> “the auspicious” [just as the Furies were called <lang>Εὐμενίδες</lang> “the gracious ones”], and to assign him the office of creation and reproduction as well as dissolution; in fact the preferential worship of <as0>Ṡiva</as0> as developed in the <asp0>Purāṇas</asp0> and Epic poems led to his being identified with the Supreme Being by his exclusive worshippers [called <asp0>Ṡaivas</asp0>]; in his character of destroyer he is sometimes called <as0>Kāla</as0> “black”, and is then also identified with “Time”, although his active destroying function is then oftener assigned to his wife under her name <as0>Kālī</as0>, whose formidable character makes her a general object of propitiation by sacrifices; as presiding over reproduction consequent on destruction <as0>Ṡiva</as0>’s symbol is the <as0>Liṅga</as0> [<ab>q.v.</ab>] or Phallus, under which form he is worshipped all over India at the present day; again one of his representations is as <as0>Ardha-nārī</as0>, “half-female”, the other half being male to symbolize the unity of the generative principle [<ls>RTL. 85</ls>]; he has three eyes, one of which is in his forehead, and which are thought to denote his view of the three divisions of time, past, present, and future, while a moon’s crescent, above the central eye, marks the measure of time by months, a serpent round his neck the measure by years, and a second necklace of skulls with other serpents about his person, the perpetual revolution of ages, and the successive extinction and generation of the races of mankind: his hair is thickly matted together, and gathered above his forehead into a coil; on the top of it he bears the Ganges, the rush of which in its descent from heaven he intercepted by his head that the earth might not be crushed by the weight of the falling stream; his throat is dark-blue from the stain of the deadly poison which would have destroyed the world had it not been swallowed by him on its production at the churning of the ocean by the gods for the nectar of immortality; he holds a <s>त्रि-शूल</s>, or three-pronged trident [also called <as0>Pināka</as0>] in his hand to denote, as some think, his combination of the three attributes of Creator, Destroyer, and Regenerator; he also carries a kind of drum, shaped like an hour-glass, called <as0>Ḍamaru</as0>: his attendants or servants are called <as0>Pramatha</as0> [<ab>q.v.</ab>]; they are regarded as demons or supernatural beings of different kinds, and form various hosts or troops called <asp0>Gaṇas</asp0>; his wife <as0>Durgā</as0> [otherwise called <as0>Kālī</as0>, <as0>Pārvatī</as0>, <as0>Umā</as0>, <as0>Gaurī</as0>, <as0>Bhavāṇī</as0> &c.] is the chief object of worship with the <asp0>Ṡāktas</asp0> and <asp0>Tāntrikas</asp0>, and in this connection he is fond of dancing [see <s>ताण्डव</s>] and wine-drinking; he is also worshipped as a great ascetic and is said to have scorched the god of love (<as0>Kāma-deva</as0>) to ashes by a glance from his central eye, that deity having attempted to inflame him with passion for <as0>Pārvatī</as0> whilst he was engaged in severe penance; in the exercise of his function of Universal Destroyer he is fabled to have burnt up the Universe and all the gods, including <as0>Brahmā</as0> and <as0>Vishṇu</as0>, by a similar scorching glance, and to have rubbed the resulting ashes upon his body, whence the use of ashes in his worship, while the use of the <as0>Rudrâksha</as0> berries originated, it is said, from the legend that <as0>Ṡiva</as0>, on his way to destroy the three cities, called <as0>Tri-pura</as0>, let fall some tears of rage which became converted into these beads: his residence or heaven is <as0>Kailāsa</as0>, one of the loftiest northern peaks of the <as0>Himâlaya</as0>; he has strictly no incarnations like those of <as0>Vishṇu</as0>, though <as0>Vīra-bhadra</as0> and the eight <asp0>Bhairavas</asp0> and <as0>Khaṇḍo-bā</as0> &c. [<ls>RTL. 266</ls>] are sometimes regarded as forms of him; he is especially worshipped at Benares and has even more names than <as0>Vishṇu</as0>, one thousand and eight being specified in the 69th chapter of the <as0>Ṡiva-Purāṇa</as0> and in the 17th chapter of the <as0>Anuṡāsana-parvan</as0> of the <as0>Mahā-bhārata</as0>, some of the most common being <as0>Mahā-deva</as0>, <as0>Ṡambhu</as0>, <as0>Ṡaṃkara</as0>, <as0>Īṡa</as0>, <as0>Īṡvara</as0>, <as0>Mahêṡvara</as0>, <as0>Hara</as0>; his sons are <as0>Gaṇêṡa</as0> and <as0>Kārttikeya</as0>), <ls>ĀṡvṠr.</ls>, <ls>MBh.</ls>, <ls>Kāv.</ls> &c., <ls>RTL. 73</ls>

column5: (<ab>opp.</ab> to <s>दुस्</s> and corresponding in sense to <ab>Gk.</ab> <lang>εὖ</lang>; perhaps connected with 1. <s>वसु</s>, and, <ab>accord.</ab> to some, with <ab>pron.</ab> base <s>स</s>, as <s>कु</s> with <s>क</s>; in <as0>Veda</as0> also <s>सू</s> and liable to become <s>षु</s> or <s>षू</s> and to lengthen a preceding vowel, while a following <s>न</s> may become <s>ण</s>; it may be used as an <ab>adj.</ab> or <ab>adv.</ab>), good, excellent, right, virtuous, beautiful, easy, well, rightly, much, greatly, very, any, easily, willingly, quickly (in older language often with other particles; <ab>esp.</ab> with <s>उ</s>, = “forthwith, immediately”; with <s>मो</s> <ab>i.e.</ab> <s>मा उ</s>, = “never, by no means”; <s>सु कम्</s> often emphatically with an <ab>Impv.</ab> <ab>e.g.</ab> <s>तिष्ठा सु कम् मघवन् मा परा गाः</s>, “do tarry O <as0>Maghavan</as0>, go not past”, <ls>RV. iii, 53, 2</ls>; <s>सु</s> always qualifies the meaning of a verb and is never used independently at the beginning of a verse; in later language it is rarely a separate word, but is mostly prefixed to substantives, adjectives, adverbs and participles, exceptionally also to an <ab>ind.p.</ab> <ab>e.g.</ab> <s>सु-बद्ध्वा</s>, “having well bound”, <ls>Mṛicch. x, 50</ls>; or even to a finite verb <ab>e.g.</ab> <s>सु-निर्ववौ</s>, <ls>Ṡiṡ. vi, 58</ls>), <ls>RV.</ls>, <ls>&c. &c.</ls>
